summary:
•	Extensive experience managing research in phytopathology and crop protection
•	Deep technical expertise in plant health
•	A unique breath of technical knowledge across biology, chemistry, genetics and biotechnology
•	Successful track record of contributing to R&D strategies and translating these into acquisition 
        of research projects    
•	Proven ability to manage and lead people to execute delivery of research results and to
        implement  these into practices for industry success 
•	Internationally orientated, strong organization and communication skills, pro-active, pragmatic and
        eager to learn
•	Broad network in academia and agri- and horticultural industry

awards.title: Jan Ritzema Bos Award
awards.description: This award is established by the Royal Netherlands Society of Plant Pathology (KNPV) to honor het best presentation during the KNPV spring meeting. The presentation  ‘An eco-metabolic approach to study host plant resistance’. by Kirsten Leiss was evaluated as the best, because eco-metabolic research was explained clearly to a broad audience. Leiss works at the department Plant Ecology and Phytochemistry of the Institute of Biology Leiden. A monetary prize of thousand Euros comes with the award.

projects.title: More with less pesticides: Host plant resistance to thrips in strawberry
projects.description: Project of 1 year duration financed by TKI and five strawberry breeders. Exploring variation of thrips resistance in strawberry and identify morhphological and chemical traits related to thrips resistance.

projects.title: Manipulating plant metabolomic profiles by seed and plant cutting treatments to enhance plant protection against western flower thrips
projects.description:
Project of four years duration within the STW perspective  programme: Green Plant Defence. Co-laboration with the Universities of Wageningen (Harry Bouwmeester ) Utrecht (Corne Pieterse), Nijmegen ( Nicole van Dam) and Amsterdam ( Michel Haring, project co-ordinator) and the companies Incotec, Rijk Zwaan, Dekker Chrysanten, Deliflor, Fides and Royal van Zanten. 

Pest resistance strongly depends on plant secondary metabolites (PSMs). Breeding programs mostly aim at increasing the levels of desired plant PSMs constitutively. In addition to this constitutive defence we can increase the level of relevant PSMs by administering them to seeds or seedlings or by induction of the plant signaling pathways. For thrips resistance especially the jasmonate (JA) pathway is relevant. For tomato we observed that in a highly resistant variety resistance was not fully developed during the first two weeks of plant growth. Because thrips is a vector of viruses it is extremely important that even the very young plant stages are well protected. The objective of this proposal is to develop methods for enhancement of resistance by (1) dipping cuttings and coating seeds with PSMs (2) induction of PSMs through activation of defence signaling pathways by (2) light treatments and (3) by non-pathogenic bacteria.

contributors.headline: Project manager - coordination of consortia at LUMC

projects.title: Physical thrips defence in tomato
projects.description: Project of 2 years duration financed by Rijk Zwaan. Development  of  genetic markers for thrips resistance in tomato based on QTL's for trichome density and exudate.

projects.title: Healthy and sustainable carrots
projects.description:
PhD project of four years duration financed by Leiden University and the Directorate of Higher Education of the Republic of Indonesia. 

The aim of this project is to develop carrots resistant to pests and pathoghens which at the same time offer an additive human health value. Phenols are secondary metabolites implicated to be involved in resistance to herbivores as well as being antioxidants implicated in human cancer, cardiovascular and Alzheimer diseases as well as diabetes. Carrots are rich in phenols. Applying an eco-metabolomic approach the metabolomic profiles of herbivore resistant and susceptible carrots will be compared to identify candidate compounds involved in plant resistance. As  pest western flower thrips (Frankliniella occidentalis) and as pathogen  the fungus carrot leaf blight  (Alternaria dauci) will be used.  Eighty-four cultivated and wild carrots accessions are available, which currently are used to construct a genetic map. Promising candidate compounds can thus be linked to the corresponding genes. In addition the effect of phenol mixtures on host plant resistance will be studied developing in-vitro bioassays for mixture studies. Also the effect of resistance to different pest biotypes will be investigated.

contributors.headline: Natural Product Researcher at Sebelas Maret University

projects.title: A metabolomics resistance test
projects.description:
STW Project of four years durationc co-financed  by the companies Dekker Chrysanten, Deliflor, Fides and Royal van Zanten.

Natural host plant defense against pests and pathogens is mainly based on secondary plant compounds. Up to now the study of chemical host plant resistance has, for technical reasons, been restricted to the identification of single compounds applying specific chemical analyses adapted to the compound in question. This is a major disadvantage because resistance is mainly based on a combination of compounds. Recent developments in plant metabolomics allow a more complete overview of secondary metabolites present in a plant. NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy) is one of the most universally used metabolomic approaches. It permits the simultaneous detection of a wide range of metabolites without prior knowledge over potential candidate compounds. In this project we will develop a metabolomic resistance test, based on NMR, facilitating a high throughput screening of resistance. The research proposed is based on an eco-metabolomic approach we developed as a proof of principle to show that NMR constitutes a major advancement in the study of host plant resistance: The metabolomic profiles of resistant and susceptible varieties will be compared to identify candidate compounds involved in resistance. The candidate compounds will then validated with in-vitro bioassays.  Using multivariate statistics models will be developed to predict resistance based on the secondary metabolites patterns. These models will be validated with a second independent resistance test with different varieties. The end result of this project is a high throughput resistance test, based on NMR to substitute time consuming and costly in vivo resistance bioassays.

contributors.headline: Teamleader Quality and Research department of Deliflor Chrysanten B.V.

projects.title: The role of phenolics in resistance to Phytophthora
projects.description:
Postgraduate Research Project of a year financed by University of Leiden. 

This research is designed to study the effects of phenols singly and in combination on the growth of different Phytophtohora species using in-vivo and in-vitro tests.

projects.title: The importance of variation of pyrrolizidine alkaloids in plant defense of Senecio
projects.description:
PhD project of four years duration financed by Leiden University and the Directorate of Higher Education of the Republic of Indonesia.

This project intends to study the origin and role of the diversity of pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PAs) and its importance for defense against generalist herbivores, such as the thrips Frankliniella occidentalis and the caterpillar Spodoptera exigua. Temporal and spatial diversification of PAs will be studied using tissue-  and cell specfic metabolomics,The role of individual PAs and PAs in mixtures, to study potential synergistic effects, will be explored by using in-vitro bioassays and insect cell cultures.

contributors.headline: Lecturer and Researcher in Gadjah Mada University, Indonesia

projects.title: Green Crop Protectants
projects.description:
Eurostar project of 5 years duration in co-operation with Institute of Agricultural Sciences, Madrid, Spain ( Azucena Gonzalez Coloma) and  the companies Trifolio (Germany), Bacamp( Spain) and Holland Biodiversity ( The Netherlands). 

Development of novel crop protectants from European Resources.  We propose a interdisciplinary search for new natrual crop protectant compounds (insecticides, insect repellents, nematicides, fungicides and weed control products).  We will construct a database on European traditional plant-derived pesticides from where plans can be selected for furhter studies. Moreover, we will explore side- and waste products from horti-and agricultrual production and processing systems fro bioactive compounds and essential oils. The project follows the model of developing new medicine or agrochemicals, a ''pipeline'' or "funnel" in which continuously new plants are entered for screening, active ones are selected for more extensive testing, including toxicity, eventually resulting in some selected plants that seem suited for further development, and if not already cultivated, will be domesticated. From the plants grown under controlled conditions formulations will be made for first field tests.

projects.title: Thrips resistance in cucumber
projects.description: Feasibiltiy study of 2 months duration financed by Enza  Zaden to study chemcial host plant reistance to  thrips in cucumber using NMR profiles.

projects.title: Thrips resistance in tomato
projects.description:
ERA-PG project for a duration of four years under the co-ordination of Peter Klinkhamer Leiden Unviversity. Co-laboration with the the Max Plank Institute for Molecular Plant Physiology Golm,Germany (Alisdair Fernie) and the John Innes Centre, Norwich, UK ( Cathie Martin).

Despite the general belief that a successful applied genomics project requires a combination of molecular, genetic, metabolomic and ecological approaches our program is one of the first to integrate this range of expertise. We intend to study a phenolic compound, chlorogenic acid (CGA), which acts as an antioxidant in plants and is expected to protect against degenerative, age related diseases. While most studies on CGA have focussed on human health aspects, our programme will study the importance of CGA for plant resistance against herbivorous insects. Specifically we want: to develop tomato lines resistant to western flower thrips (Frankliniella occidentalis) by increasing natural CGA levels. To do so we need 1) to explore the natural variation in CGA levels in tomatoes, 2) to identify the genetics behind CGA production levels, 3) to understand the relationship of CGA biosynthesis to other primary and secondary metabolite pathways, 4) to increase our understanding of the role of CGA in thrips resistance, in particular to identify possible synergy of CGA with other (phenolic) compounds and to determine the activity of various other cinnamic acid esters against thrips. When taken together this combination of targeted and broad genomic-level approaches should provide important information on the metabolic network of plant phenolic production and facilitate the engineering of plants containing elevated CGA levels without compromise in overall plant performance.

profile_positions.location: Plant Ecology and Phytochemistry, Institute of Biology, Leiden, The Netherlands
profile_positions.description: Head of the plant–herbivore resistance group,  contributing to the development of durable and sustainable plant health and crop protection focusing on  host plant resistance. Utilizing the plants own defenses forms an essential part of economic, environmental and health benefits not only for farmers but to society in general. The applied aspect of plant health has always been important to me.  Therefore, I closely co-laborated with farmers and plant breeders. This has resulted in co-laborative projects with the  agri- and horticultural industry. As  teamleader I was responsible for the development and implementation of plant health research, project acquisition- and management. Projects involved the development of in-vivo and and in-vitro bioassays, the use of metabolomic and molecular techniques. Research was conducted at laboratory, greenhouse and field level.  I guided and motivated my international team of researchers, technicians and graduate students so that together we came to result- oriented solutions.
profile_positions.title: Head of Applied Herbivore Resistance Research

profile_positions.location: Plant Ecology and Phytochemistry, Institute of Biology, Leiden, The Nehterlands
profile_positions.description: Plant health and crop protection research projects: Thrips resistance in arabidopsis and  tomato; Development of an- eco metabolomic approach to study host plant resistance; The role of phenolics in resistance to fungi; Development of in-vivo and in-vitro resistance tests for insects (thrips, aphids, leafminer) and fungi (Phytophtora infestans, P. capsici, P. cinnamomi, Aspergillus niger, Fusarium oxysporum). Development of biopesticides from flower bulbs. Chemical laboratory work and experiments in climate rooms.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.location: Plant Ecology and Phtyochemistry, Institute of Biology, Leiden, The Netherlands
profile_positions.description: Research project: Genetic variation and phenotypic plasticity in nectar production and their implications for plant reproduction through pollination. Molecular laboratory work and experiments in climate rooms and a nature reserve.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: Biological control of the weed scentless chamomille using weevils. Field work on ruderal and farm sites.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: Provided diagnosis and advice in plant health and  control of crop protection problems. Conducted research into the management of the main crop pest problems, comprising whitefly (Bemisia tabaci), american palm weevil (Rhynchoporus palmararum), pepper weevil (Anthonomus eugenii) and citrus leafminer (Phyllocnistis citrella). Assisted in the implementation of an integrated pest management project in vegetables in cooperation with the Centro Agrónomico Tropical de Investigación y Eseñanza (CATIE, Costa Rica). Responsible for training in plant health and crop pest management of farmers, extension and quarantine officers as well as a local counterpart and students of the Agricultural College. Other duties included advice in plant quarantine matters, curation and maintenance of the national insect collection and liaison with local and international ministries and organisations.
profile_positions.title: Crop Protection Officer
